title: Bakeries have been using flavoured apple PASTE in doughnuts instead of the classic filling
text:
A leading Australian bakery has revealed that the nation's favourite jam doughnut does not always consist of real jam - but often a different ingredient altogether.

Andrew Badcock, a general manager at famous bakery chain Donut King - which has a branch in Essex - has revealed doughnuts are often filled with apple sauce or flavoured paste - to ensure a smoother finish.

Despite the common belief that the baked confectionery is filled with strawberry or raspberry jam, it seems bakers have been pulling the wool over our eyes in favour of the unexpected substitute.

A leading Australian bakery has revealed that the nation's favourite jam doughnut does not always consist of real jam, but often a different ingredient altogether - apple paste

Speaking to news.com.au Andrew said: 'Some food brands use apple paste or sauce as the core ingredient in their raspberry jam recipe.

'With its natural sweetness and no pips, apple sauce is widely used for its smooth and ''jammy texture'''.

The doughnut connoisseur went on to explain that most customers preferred a smoother paste, resulting in many bakeries mixing real jam with a much lighter apple paste.

He added: 'Pips, seeds and smaller grains tend to get caught in teeth and a lot of people don’t appreciate that sensation.'

A general manager at famous bakery chain Donut King - which has a branch in Essex - has revealed doughnuts are often filled with apple sauce or flavoured paste - to ensure a smoother finish than jam

Following the shocking revelation, jam doughnut lovers took to social media to share their dismay at the news.

One disgruntled customer wrote: 'I hate doughnuts filled with a promise of jam but no jam. Boo doughnut maker, boo!'

Another person joked: 'My jam doughnut has no jam in it. I'm suing!'.

Elsewhere one outraged user tweeted: 'Shock horror- no jam in jam doughnuts.

'I always wondered why the stuff that ran out of them looked like blood! That is why I insist on home baked confections. '

General manager at the Australian chain Andrew Badcock said food brands often use apple paste or sauce as the core ingredient

Elsewhere a would-be baker advised: 'Try redcurrant jelly and butter Anglais to fill home made dough balls- so yummy!'.

But one user, who had previously worked at a bakery himself, claimed :'This is the only one of many ways to do a jam doughnut.

'Bakeries get the jam in five litre buckets and some do mix apple sauce with it to reduce the sickly sweet jam taste.

'I know this because the bakery I worked in as a kid done it this way.'
description: Leading Australian bakery Donut King has now revealed that the nation's favourite jam doughnut is not always filled with real jam but apple sauce instead.
